div.p: Hello, welcome to Trexler Library.
My name is Debbie Malone, and I'm the Library Director here.
And we're standing in the MacFadden Room in the second floor
of the library-our Salesian collection is housed here.
The library has about 150,000 bound volumes in the building.
We have about 300 paper periodicals.
But what will probably interest you the most is our online collection.
We have about 40,000 electronic books that are available to you.
We have over 25 databases that you have access to.
We provide access to about 9,000 periodical titles or magazine articles that you can access
from your home, from your office, as well as in the library,
or in any of the computer labs on campus.
I think the most important thing for you to know is that you need your DeSales ID
to access these online resources.
If you don't already have one, what you really need to do is look in your WebAdvisor profile,
and there's a library 14-digit barcode there, and that's what you'll need
to authenticate yourself into the system so you can have access to all this electronic material.
If you do have a DeSales ID, the 14-digit barcode is on the back of your ID card,
and it's very easy to find there.
We encourage you to take a look at our resources-they can really help you
with your projects in all of your courses.
One of the services we're proudest of, we offer one-on-one appointments
with public services librarians to help you with your research project.
We can do that if you come into the building, but we can we also do it over the phone
if you're never on campus, and we can do it electronically.
We've found that the librarians like to do this, and it's very beneficial to you especially
to make an appointment at the beginning of a research project
because we can help you save time and we can point you in the right direction
for all the resources we have available.
It can be a little overwhelming at first to take a look at our web page
and realize how much material is available to you there.
We're ready, willing, and able to help you to get you started on that.
And to contact us, our phone numbers are web page.
You can call any of the public services librarians and we'd be happy to work
with you to set p that appointment.
And if you need something immediately, we can certainly help you over the phone,
or email as soon as you want to contact us.
And we're always here.
Our hours are 8:30 to midnight during the week, and on Sundays.
So you're welcome to come to the building if you are on campus
and we can help directly you there.
Another important thing to look for on the library web page are online guides
to various subjects, and specifically, various majors.
If you're a business major, we have a specific guide that points you to the data bases
that would be helpful, as well as all kinds of other resources.
The other thing we've created within the last year is an online guide called Introduction
to Research.
We found that beginning students really find this useful.
If provides you information on how to get started on your paper, how to narrow your topic
or broaden your topic, and it also includes work on how to develop your thesis statement,
as well as a lot of help for creating those citations for your works cited pages.
I encourage you to find that and take a look at it.
Especially when you're writing your first paper, this can be a bit helpful for you.
And, one of the very beginning databases you might want to try
on our database page is called Academic Search Premier.
It's in the very beginning, it's at the top of the page.
It's very useful because it covers a broad range of disciplines, lots of different topics.
So it's a really good place to start doing your research to get a little overview
of your topic and get you started.
And it includes a great deal of full-text journal articles that you can get immediately.
It also indexes titles which are not in full text.
But, if we find something that's very good for your paper, and it's not available in full text,
we can get it for you through interlibrary loan.
And that's another advantage of being a DeSales student.
You can borrow books and other materials directly
from other institutions in the Lehigh Valley.
That would include Lehigh, Cedar Crest, Moravian, Muhlenberg, as well as Lafayette.
You can take your DeSales ID and borrow directly at those institutions.
And we have interlibrary loan agreements with all of those, so we get the materials
from those institutions very fast.
We also can borrow from libraries across the country
for whom we have interlibrary loan agreements.
But you know, when you need those things from another place,
you have to leave a little bit of time.
The electronic journal articles, we can get pretty fast-we can get those in a couple days.
The books may take a little bit longer, a few more days.
So you really need to plan ahead with your assignments so you get the very best work,
and you give us time to help us find the materials that we don't have available here.
Thank you for taking a look at this video.
We hope to see you in the building when you're on campus and we strongly encourage you
to take a look at the library web page so you can access the wealth
of information that's available for you here.
I hope to meet you sometime in the building.
